pullRequest.body:
*   Replaced the `requests` library needed by the Python script for SageMath API call, with native library `urllib.request`.
    *   E.g. if the user has no `pip install` rights, such as evaluation on a shared server
*   Added explicit `User-Agent` header to SageMath requests: `LeanProver (https://leanprover-community.github.io/)`. Previously, it was the default used by Python requests package `python-requests/...`.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

I am not completely sure this works in all cases where requests worked.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [b76789b405](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17605/commits/b76789b4051caf1d1d9cdcc75fd74c15e220109d)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

No declarations were harmed in the making of this PR! üêô
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.
I would also argue perhaps removing dependency on Python entirely makes sense, and we can move the logic inside Lean except for the HTTP call itself (maybe use something like `Cache.IO.runCurl`?)

In principle, rewriting Python into Lean always seems nice. I am not sure to what extend the HTTP operations are supported; that's something you'd have to find out. (There are some threads on zulip about this. Advanced features are not supported, but this PR only needs basic things.)

> In principle, rewriting Python into Lean always seems nice. I am not sure to what extend the HTTP operations are supported; that's something you'd have to find out. (There are some threads on zulip about this. Advanced features are not supported, but this PR only needs basic things.)

The simplest way to do this is just via a call to `curl`, like in Cache or LeanSearchClient. I can look into that later, but probably in a separate PR
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by grunweg.
I am also working on a PR to completely remove dependency on Python. It seems like a pretty small change
Thanks! @grunweg

Thanks!

It looks correct to me, but it's been ages since I've used `requests`, so I'd like to wait a little bit before merging in case anyone knows if there's a corner case that this `urllib`-ification is missing. I'll delegate merging to you, but please don't do `bors r+` until the following conditions are met:
1. Either 12 hours have passed or another maintainer gives this PR their 'ok'; and
2. You do one last test locally that polyrith still works with this change. I assume you tested it, but it would be good to have it on the record that it was tested.

bors d+

:v: hanwenzhu can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

I just had a moment to test it. Seems to work!

bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11296013198/job/31419976669)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11296013198/job/31419976301)

Assuming the `bytes` comment is correct (didn't double-check), this looks good to me. Thanks!
maintainer merge

The general shape looks reasonable to me, and this seems like a nice clean-up. Thanks for the PR!
I left a few detail questions inline.

Assuming the `bytes` comment is correct (didn't double-check), this looks good to me. Thanks!
maintainer merge

Clarifying to my future self: `urlencode` returns an ASCII string, and that must be encoded to bytes before using it in a request. Actually, reading the documentation --- shouldn't you encode this to bytes, using e.g. `bytes(url, 'utf-8')` where (`url` is `urllib.parse.urlencode({'code': query})`)?

> For an HTTP POST request method, data should be a buffer in the standard application/x-www-form-urlencoded format. The [urllib.parse.urlencode()](https://docs.python.org/3/library/urllib.parse.html#urllib.parse.urlencode) function takes a mapping or sequence of 2-tuples and returns an ASCII string in this format. It should be encoded to bytes before being used as the data parameter.
That's correct, I did encode the string into bytes using `.encode('utf-8')`. That is equivalent to `bytes(..., 'utf-8')` as far as I know.
Optional: capitalise the headers as `Content-Type` and `User-Agent`? (This is only a stylistic question.)
Done

Actually, `request` apparently required Python 3.8 --- so I would definitely increase the requirement here.
Given that Python 3.8 is end-of-live, I'd be happy increasing the requirement to 3.9.

That said: you're not checking that version anywhere, are you?

I am not checking that version anywhere.

I don't think request requires Python 3.8. `urllib.request` was added with Python 3.

If you mean the package `requests` that was removed, it has [versions](https://pypi.org/project/requests/2.17.3/) for Python all the way back to Python 2. Although probably those versions are not actively maintained anymore.

Ah, the page I checked showed the requests package requiring Python 3.8. I had not checked for backported versions...

I don't think committing to support 3.6 makes sense --- but if the current code incidentally supports it, saying this is the minimum is fine. With the understanding that any bug specific to Python 3.6 will not be fixed, and the Python requirement bumped instead.

In other words: you could also say "has Python 3 installed" --- which is deliberately unclear, but under most readings does not include end-of-life'd versions. Perhaps that's better; what do you think?
Ah, definitely that makes sense!
The documentation is now reverted to `python3` installed and available on path

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(Tactic/Polyrith): remove Python `requests` dependency in SageMath call
